text: Number 21, Chicago and North Western Railway Company versus Chicago Milwaukee St. Paul & Pacific Company et al.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
The uniform freight classification, Mr. Justice Stewart.
As far as classification, we do not have a term any longer that says first class, fifth class.
-- and they take 20%, we'll say, or 14% of the first class rating.
Quite low rated as the Commission did find sir.
Mr. Justice Goldberg, I would submit this that the only support for that finding could be two photographs that were attached to the complaint to the District Court for the first time.
It is in the answer of the government and the Interstate Commerce Commission and let me get this accurately for Your Honor.

We do submit Your Honor that the only place it could've come to the Court, as shown on page 3 of this record, however, is from the extraneous phonographs which we did suggest were not properly before that court.
Well, would you answer his question please?
Is it that character of terrain there?
In my personal observation Your Honor --
-- there exists one significant iron ore mine, and in the immediate vicinage, I see no industrial community.
This -- the court here recognized that, and I read their opinion on page 391 that in the Missouri-Pacific case trade had already -- have always been interchanged between the two lines.
That is correct, it really did.
Says the connection was to be used to interchange freight with formally had been interchanged between them via the Missouri-Pacific.
-- and decisive distinction between this case and the Missouri-Pacific case?
It might be Your Honor and let me elaborate that.
In my opinion Your Honor, no.
I don't know, Mr. Justice Black.
Did you construct a new one?
We constructed 262 feet of track Your Honor, and in my opinion this is not a construction of a line of railroad, it's a switching track yes sir.

The Milwaukee and Ishpeming filed an application under Section 5 requesting authority to jointly use the main line of the Ishpeming for the purpose of returning the Milwaukee's locomotive to its own line.
No, I don't Your Honor, because I --
I don't believe it is, because because what the Commission did rely on was not the fact that we had extended our line to a new destination which of course was not the case.
The switching track is not an extension but in my opinion, the Interstate Commerce Commission said the track is an extension because of these other effects.
No Mr. Justice Black, I do not believe so.
This is our case precisely because it is a switching track it is not an extension.
Well, do you acknowledge any -- I don't know what you call it, expertise or something like that.
And very properly so, Your Honor.
Why isn't that this kind of a case?
In the cases where the expertise of the Commission should be respected, the issues are such as to involve factual administrative determinations.

Why I remember forgotten the trial of the case but we have one here a couple of years ago whether or not -- in one trucking area, whether or not a given operation by furniture manufacturer was a contract carriage or private carriage.
Well yes, the legal issue is whether it's an extension or a switching line, isn't it?
Well, now how -- what are the standards which judges can apply to decide whether it's one or the other on these facts?
Congress has not set out in these sections of the Act any definitive standard.
Well that was a seven mile long extension or something, isn't it?
Yes, but the argument was made in that case, sir that the court should respect the Commission's expertise in deciding the question and this Court said no.
Mr. Long perhaps in respect with our record but when we assume the Commission found this extension not the Commission right?

What if the Commission says that as probably the fact here that his was not only a switching track but a switching track between two different lines and one that had a substantial impact upon the traffic patterns in the two lines.
Is that true or isn't it that --
-- there is no dispute about the facts that this is the fact here?
But it did have substantial impact on traffic and was the connection between two lines and it was new track that they never had before?
What's the purpose of giving the Commission power to pass upon an extension?
It's clear from decisions of this Court sir.
I'd like to answer several specific questions, if I may.
But for authorized the movement of through routes makes (Inaudible).
If they had made such a finding Mr. Justice Black.
Alright, let me make this point.
Can you justify the claim under 118 of designating something as an extension even more than nothing but conviction --
-- you raised this question earlier Mr. Justice Black.
But you did raise in which case that this particular point been raised and decided?
Alabama and Vicksburg, it is decided at -- we've set out in two of the briefs.
Did that specifically settled that point?
Specifically and the Tex-Mex case likewise specifically settles that point.

Well in those case Mr. Danielson, goes so far as I read this excerpt at page 298 that the Commission were to say that the creation of the connection enable the defendants to compete for traffic which therefore was adequately served by other carriers, does it go that far?

These are independent determinations of public convenience not of jurisdiction Your Honor, but we would take the position Mr. Justice Brennan that its findings on public convenience ought to be findings treated for the jurisdictional element as well.
For purpose is of one is an extension with in line --
Section 118 having jurisdiction then requires the Commission to determine whether public convenience and necessity --
Talking about this case, nobody else is complaining.
These carriers here are -- these carriers here are weakening themselves respectfully, so --
And at our expense because the record shows --
(Inaudible) that the purpose presented to me speak in terms of what the carrier has built the expense and does it himself?

Or by another carrier establishing a line competing which is superfluous as the Commission found this connection to be, because prior to this establishment of this connection each and every law, each and every pound of sawdust if you will, every bit of traffic that moved was moving over the light density line which we had heretofore operated for almost 100 years in that territory.
Which railroad are we speaking of sir?
The ownership is established red 130 feet Milwaukee, blue 130 feet L.S.& I, blue another roughly 100.
It is owned in turn by the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company.

That is the principal shipper this record shows from the origin Sunrise Landing to a nonaffiliated consumer at the destination Iron Mountain which we serve, we the Chicago and Northwestern like the Milwaukee Road.
Did the rates change after this case?
The record shows no change in rates, no change in distance, no change in any element.
